comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I'd have said 1899 - 1915, myself. The houses are in this picture and are still there now, but weren't there in 1899.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] Yet the following photo is next in the numbering system and dated 1908!! ??

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland/7465386310]

edit - one of my all time favorites....

edit 2 - Carol I see that you were surprised by the location as it was in with photos of Bantry, so catalog chronology may not be 100%

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] 1908 seems a good bet then (see my previous post).

comment.author: 8468254@N02
comment._content: The telegraph office is mentioned as far back as 1875, so that's no help.

comment.author: 79549245@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] I see, the [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] "Thanks for the date. So now we're down to 1890-1899" confused me. Young Miss Carol may still be in holiday mode!! That said, I am very happy shes back and posting dogs.

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Mea Culpa!  :(  [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] 

Was distracted by amusing colleague here in the garret of Library Towers - won't let it happen again!

So, thanks to [http://www.flickr.com/photos/8468254@N02] the date is now 1899-1915.
Though, I'd be cautious about assuming 1908 from the glass negative numbers... (as [http://www.flickr.com/photos/79549245@N06] notes above we can't rely on catalogue chronology)

comment.author: 79549245@N06

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I forgive you. As an aside I have been looking at SECRETS OF THE IRISH LANDSCAPE on the RTE player, wherin they pay great attention to an ex colleague of yours a Mr Robert Lloyd Praeger and his book "The Way that I went".

Very interesting documentary - I would recommend it.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: The 1901 census shows that the shop with the five dormers was run by a Robert Wolfe. The 1911 census has no mention of any Wolfes living in Ballydehob. One could then speculate that the above photograph pre-dates 1911.. Wolfe's shop today. My Beautiful Launderette

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Excellent, thank you! Did find one Wolfe in 1911 - Hester, 67, blind and a boarder with the Roycrofts...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment._content: That's a really great shot. Lots of interest in the foreground and a wonderful backdrop.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/nlireland] I saw that...but she is listed as having been a farmer out in Stouke which is a townland about 1Km out the Schull road.

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: Here is Elizabeth Wolfe and her daughter Christine/Christina in 1911. She is a widow.

comment.author: 91549360@N03

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] I was only looking for the Wolfes who ran that shop in Ballydehob!

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Same as that. There seems to have been an exodus from Ballydehob itself after 1901. Maybe the shop retained the name, and you're right thinking, it was managed by family from outside the parish. The House and Buildings return for 1901 show that Robert S Wolfe owned 14 of the 32 building listed in Ballydehob town. Looks like Ballydehob could well have been called Wolfetown.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: The 1911 census Building Return shows that Wolfes shop, House #22, was by then a public house and occupied by a Jane Kearney. So photo most likely pre 1911. Robert Wolfe is not listed as being landlord of any property in Ballydehob in 1911. Strange?

comment.author: 30369211@N00
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] It's not strange - he was dead.

The Elizabeth Wolfe I linked above was his widow.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/gnmcauley] Well that answers that. :)

comment.author: 75556178@N05
comment._content: Wolfes AND a dog.

comment.author: 92418093@N08
comment._content: A great photo.  And excellent detective work to match. Added to my Faves.

comment.author: 91549360@N03
comment._content: From the Gardeners Chronicle JANUARY 2, 1904 John Atkins & Co. ” The above-named company has been registered with a capital of £16,000, in £1 shares, for the purpose of acquiring as a going concern and carrying on the business of seed merchants and agricultural implements now carried on by John Atkins & Co. and Joseph Wolfe, in the city and counties of Cork and Kerry, under the style of John Atkins & Co. The first directors are John Atkins, merchant, Dunmanway, Co. Cork, and Joseph Wolfe, Douglas Road, Cork. Registered office : 6, Camden Quay, The signatories to the articles are : J. Atkins, merchant, Cork J.Wolfe, merchant, Cork Elizabeth Wolfe, married woman, Cork W. Wolfe, merchant, Ichull R. Wolfe, merchant, Ballydehob J. B. Atkins, merchant, Dumanway ... W. H. Atkins, merchant, Cork Atkins are run by Wolfes today. So maybe photo taken closer to 1904?

comment.author: 91870729@N06
comment._content: Ballydehob was previously known as Swantonstown

comment.author: 91870729@N06
comment._content: From Ballydehob website "The 17th century saw an influx of settlers mainly from England, but a significant number were also Protestants (Huguenots) fleeing persecution in Catholic France. The Swantons from Norfolk became the most prominent family in the locality and by the late 18th century they had succeeded in changing the name of Ballydehob to Swanton’s Town. (The last known use of the name Swanton’s Town was in the census of 1821)."

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/91549360@N03] Really excellent find! So, name over the door would have been Atkins from very early 1904 then? Or might they have kept the familiar name for a bit longer? And what amazing longevity for the Wolfes within Atkins! I'm changing this one to 1899-1904, and I'll try to dig out our Almanacs for Cork City and County tomorrow. Hopefully Ballydehob features...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/silensol] Very interesting, thank you! And I found an article on the Swantons from the archives of the Southern Star newspaper too...
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons

comment.author: 47290943@N03
comment._content:
Slight spanner in dating work! I checked through a number of Cork City and County Almanacs, and Wolfe (the Wolves) appears right up until 1910 in the list of Shopkeepers, etc. in Ballydehob:
Wolfe & Co., general merchants and posting establishment
comment.authorname: National Library of Ireland on The Commons
